INCAPE, Colectora Ruta Nac Nº 168 Km. 0 - Paraje El Pozo Santa Fe 3000 Argentina The conversion of methanol to olefins (MTO, T = 400 and 450 °C, WHSV=4 h-1) was studied using ZSM5, SAPO34 and amorphous silica-aluminas (different percentages of SiO2, 40%, 60% and 70%) (commercial catalysts) treated or not by HCl. All the catalysts studied present type IV adsorption/desorption isotherms of N2. The incorporation of HCl decreased the surface area, increased the pore size, the total acidity and the quantity and strength of Brønsted acid sites. The increase in the reaction temperature favors the yield of ethylene to a greater extent than that of propylene. The highest light olefins yield was obtained with catalysts containing 60% SiO2 at 400ºC. Its good performance is attributed to the combination of adequate acidity, high specific surface area, and small pore size. Catalysts with 40% SiO2 are not suitable for MTO. The addition of HCl to the aluminosilicates cause further deactivation. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Methanol MTO Propylene Ethylene SiO2-Al2O3 Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Light olefins, mainly ethylene and propylene, are petrochemicals with multiple applications [1]. It is important to note that the demand for propylene is constantly increasing due to the growing need for its derivatives [2]. The conversion of methanol to olefins (MTO) is an alternative technology to hydrocarbon steam cracking (SC) that allows to vary the ratio of propylene/ethylene and has greater energy efficiency. In addition, it generates about one ton less CO2 per ton of olefins than SC. The starting point of the MTO reaction on acidic zeolites is the formation of methoxy groups on the surface as key-reactive intermediates [SiO(CH3)Al] [3], which are then converted to olefins by different routes [4]. Acidic zeolites, such as ZSM5 or SAPO34 [5–12], also induce a shape selectivity and numerous studies postulate that the pore structure and the properties of the Brønsted acid sites of zeolite catalysts have an important effect on the yields of the desired reaction products and on the products distribution [13–16]. SAPO34 is considered an excellent catalyst for this reaction; due to its moderate acid strength and small pore size [14] that generates high selectivity to light olefins. The small pores of SAPO34 (0.43 nm) restrict the diffusion of the large molecules of intermediates (aromatics and heavy and/or branched hydrocarbons), although the small molecules of light olefins escape from these pores, leadings to high selectivity to light olefins. The main drawback of this catalyst is its rapid deactivation, starting when aromatics and heavy branched compounds are formed inside the large cages. These molecules cannot diffuse through the porous structure of the catalyst because their kinetic diameter is larger than the pore opening size. Therefore, they remain inside the cages where they can form carbonaceous deposits that block the pore openings and prevent the access of molecules to the active sites [17]. ZSM5 zeolite catalyst is used industrially in Exxon-Mobil's MTO process, but coke deposition is the main cause of deactivation [18,19]. Coke compounds may adsorb on the acid sites of the ZSM5 zeolite, poisoning the catalyst active centers. Olsbye et al. studied the deactivation process of several zeolitic materials in the methanol-to-hydrocarbons (MTH) and MTO processes [20–22]. They concluded that the formation of coke during the MTO reaction on ZSM5 crystals significantly differs from that on SAPO34 crystals. Pore blocking in ZSM5 zeolite has been related to the formation of polyaromatic compounds at the channel intersections or on the outer surface, while in SAPO34 it arises from polyaromatic molecules formed in the large cavities [23]. The differences in pore architecture of these materials affect the coke formation and therefore the activity of the catalyst. ZSM5 is less sensitive to deactivation compared to SAPO34, but it has a lower selectivity towards light olefins [24]. The topology, acidity, and particle size of zeolites affect the catalytic performance of MTO reactions, particularly the light olefins selectivity and lifetime. In order to optimize catalytic performance, numerous investigations were aimed at controlling the acidic properties of the catalyst such as concentration, strength and the type (Brønsted/Lewis) [25–29]. In addition, variations in structure type modify crystallinity and mesoporosity and influence catalytic behavior in the MTO reaction [30]. The catalyst lifetime and performance were improved by increasing the mesoporosity [31,32]. Product distribution depends not only on the type of catalyst but also on the operating conditions. Recently, Lissens et al. [33] in the study of the effect of Si/Al ratio over HZSM5 zeolites found that with Si/Al = 25 ratio, the lowest studied, and increasing the temperature, the reaction pathways with more C3-C5 olefins produced. Conversely, the increase in the Si/Al ratio can improve the propylene selectivity and lifetime of Beta zeolites [34,35]. Consequently, mesoporous amorphous silica-alumina (ASA) appears as good candidates for MTO reaction. They not only contain mixed silica-alumina phases, but also pure silica and alumina groups [36]. These have strong Brønsted acid sites, with a strength comparable to that of zeolites, but at a much lower concentration that can be adjusted by modifying the composition of SiO2 and Al2O3 [37]. The addition of chlorine is another way to increase the number of acid sites [38]. The present work studies the conversion of methanol to olefins using amorphous aluminosilicates of different composition SiO2-Al2O3. It seeks to determine the incidence in the distribution of products of the composition and incorporation of chlorine to these amorphous materials and compare them with commercial catalysts ZSM5 and SAPO34. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The SiO2-Al2O3 ASA supports (Siral 40, 60 and 70) provided by SASOL were calcined for 4 h at 450 °C (10 °C min-1, air, 60 cm3 min-1). These catalysts are named Sx, where x = 40, 60 and 70 is the percentage of SiO2. In addition, 1.5 cm3 g-1 of HCl (0.2 M) was added to these supports. After 1 h the support was dried at 70 °C in a thermostatically controlled water-bath until dry powder was obtained and left one night in the oven at 110 °C. Finally, it was calcined in airflow (60 cm3 min-1, 300 °C, 4 h). These catalysts are indicated SxHCl. The calcination of ZSM5 (commercial, Zeocat Pentasil PZ-2/54, SiAl = 20, Na2O = 2.3 wt%) was performed at 500 °C, 8 h (2 °C min-1, air, 60 cm3 min-1). SAPO34 zeolite, provided by ZR Catalyst Co. LTD, was calcined at 500 °C, 8 h (2 °C min-1, air, 60 cm3 min-1). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The measurements the specific surface area were made in a Micromeritics ASAP-2000 equipment. The BET (surface area) method was applied; and the BJH method (pore volume and diameter) using N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms. Previously, the samples were subjected to vacuum 1 h at 200 °C. The samples were analyzed in an energy dispersive X-ray fluorescence spectrometer, Shimadzu Model EDX-720, using Fundamental Parameters to determine SiO2, Al2O3 and P2O5 content. Each solid sample was placed in a sample holder with a polypropylene window and subsequently received a vacuum drying treatment. The analysis X-ray Diffraction (XRD) was performed with an Empyrean XRD diffractometer. Diffraction patterns were recorded using Cu Kα radiation filtered with Ni in a range of 10–80° at a scanning speed of 2º min-1, operating at 30 kV and 40 mA. The acidic function of the catalysts was characterized by pyridine temperature programmed desorption (pyridine TPD). 200 mg samples were impregnated with pyridine at room temperature. The excess evaporated under the hood until dry powder was obtained. In N2 flow (40 cm3 min-1) at 110 °C for 1 h, the weakly adsorbed pyridine was removed. Then the temperature rose to 750 °C (10 °C min-1). The desorbed pyridine was measured by connecting the reactor outlet to a flame ionization detector (FID). Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine was used to determine the number of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites on the catalysts. Self-supported wafers with a diameter of 16 mm and a weight of 20–25 mg were used. Each wafer was pretreated in air flow at 450 °C (heating rate of 2 °C min-1) for 12 h. Then the temperature was decreased at 200 °C and the cell containing the wafer was treated under ultra-high vacuum for 1 h for removing all physisorbed species. The cell containing the wafer was then cooled to 150 °C, a reference spectrum was measured and pyridine was injected into the system (250 Pa, 5 min). The non-adsorbed excess was eliminated by application of a vacuum (2 x 10-3 Pa, 1 h). The IR absorption spectrum was measured in a Nicolet 750 Magna instrument (2 cm-1 resolution). The total amount of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was calculated using the following expression: Q μ mol g − 1 = 1000 AS ε m where A is the integrated area of the infrared bands at 1455 cm-1 (Lewis sites) and 1546 cm-1 (Brønsted sites) in absorbance units (cm-1); ε is the molar extinction coefficient ( ɛ L = 1.28 μ mol-1 for the pyridine Lewis band [39] and ɛ B = 1.13 μ mol-1 for Brønsted acid sites [40]; S is the surface area of the wafer (cm2), and m is the wafer mass (mg). By temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) coke was continuously oxidized from the 60–75 mg samples under a flow of 5% O2/N2 (% vol, 60 cm3 min-1) increasing the temperature from 30 °C to 750 °C (10 °C min-1). The outlet gases were fed to a methanator, where CO2 and CO were quantitatively converted to CH4 over a Ni/Kieselguhr catalyst in the presence of H2 that was analyzed by GC using an FID detector. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The conversion of methanol to olefins was carried out in continuous flow in a fixed bed reactor at atmospheric pressure. Previously, the samples (100 mg) were treated 1 h in N2 flow at 550 °C. Reaction conditions: methanol flow = 0.5 cm3 h-1, space velocity WHSV = 4 h-1, reaction temperatures: 400 and 450 °C. The products were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) with a flame ionization detector (FID) (Thermo Scientific Trace 1300, capillary column Phenomenex ZB-1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization The pore volumes and diameters shown in Table 1 indicate that the aluminosilicates studied are mesoporous materials, while SAPO34 presents micropores. ZSM5 is also known to be a microporous support, in line with the value of porous volume Vp of 0.2 cm3/g, and the high value of pore diameter is due to the interparticular volume. SxHCl catalysts have a larger pore diameter, and smaller specific surface area and pore volume than the Sx series. The effect of chlorine on textural properties (Table 1) is most noticeable in catalysts that have 70% SiO2. On the other hand, the ZSM5 catalyst shows the lowest specific surface area of the catalysts studied, while the catalysts with 60% SiO2 have the highest specific surface area and the smallest diameter and pore volume of the aluminosilicates studied. In the SxHCl series there are no significant changes in the percentage of chlorine with the SiO2 content, as shown in Table 1, previously reported results [38]. Fig. 1 shows that the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of the catalysts are type IV according to the IUPAC classification [41]. The observed hysteresis (0.7 <P/P0 <0.95) is more pronounced in the Sx and SxHCl catalyst series and indicates the presence of mesopores. In addition, the type IV hysteresis loop may be associated with the presence of narrow slit-like pores. The analysis of the pore size distribution (BJH desorption branch, Fig. 2) displays the great difference that exists in the distribution of the pore size of the catalysts ZSM5 and SAPO34 with respect to the ASAs. In addition, it is observed that the catalysts S60 and S60HCl have a similar pore size distribution. SAPO34 features a wide pore size distribution. XRD profiles of catalysts are presented in Fig. 3. It is observed that the Sx and SxHCl series have a wide peak at 2θ = 23–24°, characteristic of an amorphous aluminosilicate structure [42]. Except for S70, it is observed that the addition of chlorine modifies the crystal structure. The increase in silica content produces a remarkable growth of the halo at 2θ = 20–30° due to the amorphous phase of SiO2. Diffraction peaks present at 2θ = 37.5, 39.6, 46 and 67.4° can be attributed to γ-Al2O3 [38]. The diffraction peaks due to SiO2 and Al2O3 show that both phases exist separately in the Sx series, although the diffraction peaks of Al2O3 practically disappear in the case of S70. The ZSM5 diffractogram exhibits well-defined typical peaks with doublets and triplets ranging from 2θ = 7–10° and 23–25°, respectively, suggesting the presence of an MFI crystal lattice [43]. SAPO34 diffraction peaks at 9.5°, 12.8°, 16°, 20.5°, 26°, and 31° corresponding to the (101), (110), (021), (211), (220), and (401) planes, confirm CHA structure [44]. Fig. 4 shows the total acidity determined by pyridine TPD and the distribution of acid sites, classified according to the desorption temperature into: weak (T < 300 °C), moderate (300 < T < 500 °C) and strong (T > 500 °C). It can be observed that the total acidity and number of weak acid sites of SxHCl catalysts are greater than those of their Sx analogues. The S60 and S60HCl catalysts exhibit the highest total acidity of each of the corresponding series, while the S40 catalyst has the lowest total acidity of the catalysts studied, followed by S40HCl. On the other hand, the total acidity of the ZSM5 catalyst is significantly higher than that of the other catalysts and has mostly weak sites. In addition, it has virtually the same number of moderate acid sites as S60. Regarding the distribution of moderate and strong acid sites, if the SxHCl series are compared to Sx series catalysts containing 60% SiO2 exhibit the opposite behavior to the rest; that is, they present a decrease in moderate acid sites and an increase in strong acid sites with the addition of chlorine. The SAPO34 catalyst has the lowest acidity of all studied catalysts. Fig. 5 shows the pyridine FTIR spectra obtained at 150 °C. In the catalyst Sx and SxHCl series, the infrared bands at 1455 cm-1 and 1546 cm-1 associated with the Lewis and Brønsted sites respectively are observed. In the range 1612–1630 cm-1 are the IR absorption peaks of pyridine adsorbed on medium and strong Lewis acid sites. Peak at 1490 cm-1 corresponds to pyridine adsorbed in Lewis and Brønsted acid centers [45]. In order to determine the strength of the acid sites, pyridine FTIR was performed at different desorption temperatures. Brønsted and Lewis acid sites are presented in Table 2. It is observed that the Brønsted acidity increases with the content of Si. The results of FTIR-Py reflect that the incorporation of Cl produces an increase in the amount and strength of Brønsted acid sites, in accordance with what Ozimek reported for alumina [46]. It can also be noted that the Brønsted/Lewis acid site ratio decreases with increasing pyridine desorption temperature. It can be said that in general terms, the trend in total acidity, found by pyridine TPD is confirmed by FTIR-Py. 3.2 Catalytic performance Preliminary experiments were carried out, where the catalytic performance of ZSM5 was evaluated at 350, 400 and 450 °C and different WHSV (1, 2 and 4 h-1) to establish the reaction conditions of methanol to olefins. Table 3 shows the results of methanol conversion and selectivities to the different MTO reaction products obtained using the ZSM5 catalyst at 4 h reaction conducted at different temperatures and WHSV = 4 h-1. The widely accepted double-cycle reaction mechanism for the conversion of methanol to olefins considers that at low reaction temperatures the aromatic cycle has preponderance while at high reaction temperatures the olefin cycle is favored [13,15,47]. The results shown in Table 3 are in accordance with this mechanism, because it is observed that the increase in the reaction temperature leads to a lower selectivity to aromatic products and increases of the selectivity to light olefins. The methanol conversion data (XMeOH) during the reaction at 400 and 450 °C and WHSV = 4 h-1 obtained with all catalysts are presented in Fig. 6. It is observed that at both reaction temperatures the catalysts ZSM5 and SAPO34 achieve the highest conversion. These catalysts have very different structure and acidity, ZSM5 has tenfold amount of acid sites than SAPO34. In the case of the ZSM5 catalyst the high conversion is attributed to its high acidity, crystallinity and small pore size [16]. The largest pore-sized aluminosilicates (S40, S40HCl and S70HCl) at 400 °C initially have an XMeOH of less than 75%. The increase in the reaction temperature from 400 ºC to 450 ºC leads to higher methanol conversions, all catalysts achieve methanol initial conversions above 80%. The catalysts of the SxHCl series show a higher initial conversion than their Sx counterparts, except for de S70HCl, but a marked decrease in conversion as a function of time whatever the temperatures. Thus, the ASA with the highest initial methanol conversion (> 90 at 450 °C, S60HCl), strongly deactivates to reach 60% of methanol conversion after 4 h of reaction. Fig. 7 shows the yield to propylene and ethylene obtained at different reaction times and temperature. It can be observed that the yield to ethylene is increased more than to propylene with increasing reaction temperature, except with the catalysts that contain 60% SiO2. This is because the increase in the reaction temperature produces the cracking of propylene and C4+, increasing the formation of ethylene. Ethylene and propylene are formed through different pathways. Propylene and higher olefins are largely formed from alkene methylations and interconversions (such as cracking reactions) [48]. Catalysts S40 and S40HCl have very low yields to light olefins at both reaction temperatures, mostly producing alkanes and alkenes of C4. The highest performance to propylene, ∼45%, is obtained with the S60 catalyst at 400 °C and with S70 at 450 °C. At 400 ºC with the S60 and S70HCl catalysts, the yield of propylene obtained with the SAPO34 and ZSM5 is exceeded. While S70HCl at 5 min reaction presents highest performance at propylene at both reaction temperatures, it is then exceeded by S60 at 400 °C and S70 at 450 °C. The high ethylene yield obtained with the S60HCl catalyst can be attributed to its high acidity, since strong acid sites favor the cracking of heavy compounds to light olefins, leading to higher yields of ethylene than propylene [19]. Fig. 8 shows the selectivity to light olefins at 5 min of reaction at 400 and 450 °C as a function of the total acidity determined by TPD of pyridine. It should be mentioned that, for a given catalyst, the selectivity into light olefins is virtually unaffected by the conversion. The results obtained with SAPO34 are in agreement with that reported by other authors attributed to it has small pore entrances which allow only the diffusion of linear hydrocarbons thus inhibiting production of aromatic [49,50]. With the ZSM5 catalyst, which presents the highest total acidity of the catalysts studied, selectivities to C2 = and C3 = are comparable to those published by other authors [51] if the low deactivation of this catalyst is taken into account. On the other hand, in the ASA series of Sx and SxHCl catalysts, the increase in total acidity leads to the increase in selectivity to light olefins, and 100% selectivity to propylene and ethylene can be obtained with the most acidic amorphous silica-alumina, namely S60HCl. The most selective catalysts, S60 and S60HCl, are also the ones presenting the lowest pore diameters Dp (Table 1) of the ASA series. But S70HCl, presenting the highest Dp value, is not the less selective of the ASA series. Consequently, it can be inferred that the acidity is a major parameter governing the selectivity for the non zeolitic silica-alumina catalysts. A summary of the results obtained on the various catalysts after 4 h of MTO reaction is reported in Table 4. The ethylene/propylene ratio increases with the increase in reaction temperature attributed to the secondary reaction of oligomerization and cracking that are favored when the reaction temperature increases [52]. This is verified for all catalysts except for ZSM5 and S60HCl that remains constant. The ethylene/propylene ratio obtained for SAPO34 is in the range 0.7–1.2 reported for fixed bed reactors [13, 53–55]. The formation of carbonaceous deposits during MTO conversion was studied by temperature programmed oxidation (TPO). Results are reported in Fig. 9 and the amount of coke deposit is reported in Table 4. It is verified that the increase of the reaction temperature leads to greater deposition of coke. Surprisingly, there is no link between the amount of coke deposit and the deactivation observed for methanol conversion, since the sample S60HCl is the most deactivated and it presents among the lowest amount of coke deposit. The highest formation of coke is obtained with SAPO34 at both reaction temperatures. The deactivation of SAPO34 catalyst is a common problem in MTO process. Due to its shape selectivity to olefins, SAPO34 is one of the best zeolites for this purpose, but this advantage also makes its deactivation faster and more pronounced due to pore blockage or coke formation [56]. On the other hand, it can be noted that the structure of ZSM5 effectively promotes the diffusion of aromatic intermediates and reduces their residence time in the pore channel, thus inhibiting rapid deposition of coke [51]. Thus, the differences in structure framework and pore size between SAPO34 and ZSM5 explain the large deactivation of the first catalyst. At both reaction temperatures the addition of HCl to catalysts S40 and S60 decreases a little the formation of coke, while for S70 an important increase is observed. This can be attributed to the large number of strong acid sites in S70 (Fig. 4) which are mainly responsible for the formation of coke. Fig. 9 shows that the combustion of coke deposited on the support occurs at higher temperatures when the Treation increases from 400 to 450 °C. Catalysts S60 and S60HCl have coke content similar to ZSM5, however, the coke combustion temperature of the latter is higher, in particular at 450 °C. Sx series TPO profiles change dramatically with reaction temperature. The higher deactivation of the SxHCl catalyst series compared to its Sx analogs can be attributed to the loss of chlorine during the reaction. It was verified by EDX that, at the end of the reaction, the Cl content in the catalysts of the first series is practically zero. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, at the two reaction temperatures studied, the methanol conversion obtained with the amorphous silica-alumina catalysts (ASA) was lower than that achieved with the catalysts ZSM5 and SAPO34. However, at 400 ºC at 4 h of reaction with the use of ASA catalysts (except those with 40% SiO2) higher yields in light olefins are obtained than with the ZSM5 catalyst (at both reaction temperatures). In particular, the catalyst containing 60% SiO2 at 400 ºC exceeds the yield to propylene and ethylene obtained with the SAPO34 catalyst. Therefore, with ASA catalysts (%wt SiO2 ≥ 60) it is possible to work at a lower temperature and achieve high yields of light olefins. In addition, at both reaction temperatures the % of C deposited on the ASA catalysts is lower than that of SAPO34 and the temperature programmed oxidation - profiles show that the coke combustion of the ASA catalysts (except S40 at 450 ºC) is produced at lower temperatures than SAPO34 catalysts. Finally, the percentage of coke obtained with catalysts containing 60% SiO2 are similar to those found for ZSM5 and the ethylene and propylene performance of the first catalysts is higher, even after 4 h reaction. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of methanol to olefins (MTO, T = 400 and 450 °C, WHSV=4 h-1) was studied using ZSM5, SAPO34 and amorphous silica-aluminas (different percentages of SiO2, 40%, 60% and 70%) (commercial catalysts) treated or not by HCl. All the catalysts studied present type IV adsorption/desorption isotherms of N2. The incorporation of HCl decreased the surface area, increased the pore size, the total acidity and the quantity and strength of Brønsted acid sites. The increase in the reaction temperature favors the yield of ethylene to a greater extent than that of propylene. The highest light olefins yield was obtained with catalysts containing 60% SiO2 at 400ºC. Its good performance is attributed to the combination of adequate acidity, high specific surface area, and small pore size. Catalysts with 40% SiO2 are not suitable for MTO. The addition of HCl to the aluminosilicates cause further deactivation.
coredata.dc:title: SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts for methanol to olefins: Comparative study with SAPO34 and ZSM5
